The name for this idea is "feature-selective NEAT" (FS-NEAT), and it 
is de=
scribed in detail in this paper:

http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/keyword?whiteson:=
gecco05

It is true as Peter says that the rtNEAT source code is already 
c=
apable of doing this.  My own regular NEAT code will have some 
problems si=
nce it was not set up to retain disconnected structure 
from one generation=
 to the next.  But the rtNEAT release contains a 
fix for that.

In any cas=
e, it's fairly easy to implement in any version of NEAT.

--- In neat@yahoo=
groups.com, "petar_chervenski"

t your evolution with many inputs disconnected. Let's say

enome has only one connection, in the next 
generations

dd more, and only these networks that have useful 
> inputs connected are s=
elected.. This can be slow, however, if the 
> mutation rate is too low..

 way.
